p: The recent surge in climate litigation, characterized by a notable uptick in cases filed since 2015, is testament to the growing recognition of the potential value of using litigation as a tool for climate action. The rising trend in cases filed (Fig 1) indicates a growing expectation that actors ought to be held accountable for actions which wreak havoc on the environment and threaten the prospect of sustaining a climate compatible with human life. These temporal trends are generally consistent with findings from other studies which have documented a relatively consistent rise in both US- and non-US-filed climate litigation cases [84].
